Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ensure animation @trigger ordering is correctly delivered to the renderer
Issues.Body:
In Ivy when elements are created a series of static attribute names are provided
over to the construction instruction of that element. Static attribute names
include non-binding attribues (like `<div selected>`) as well as animation bindings
that do not have a RHS value (like `<div @foo>`). Because of this distinction,
value-less animation triggers are rendered first before value-full animation
bindings are and this improper ordering has caused various existing tests to fail.
This patch ensures that animation bindings are evaluated in the order that they
exist within the HTML template code (or host binding code).

Issues.Title: Angular language service - error when using ngIf and strictNullChecks
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
@angular/language-service


### Is this a regression?

No.


### Description

Language service is not working correctly with `ngIf` and `strictNullChecks`.

There is a [documentation](https://angular.io/guide/template-syntax#the-non-null-assertion-operator---) about this exact thing, but it makes no sense because of the following:

1. **Following TypeScript code is OK with full `strict` mode enabled**

```typescript
public obj?: { val: string };

if (this.obj) {
  console.log(this.obj.val); // IT'S ALL GOOD
}
```

2. **The same logic in Angular template throws an error trough language service:**

```html
<ng-container *ngIf="obj">{{ obj.val }}</ng-container>
```

This really makes no sense, and the official solution is to add `!` after `obj`, like `{{ obj!.val }}` which feels more like a workaround.

I did as well found out that creating a variable in ngIf directive will prevent the error from appearing, therefore it is inconsistent as well:

```html
<ng-container *ngIf="obj; let obj">{{ obj.val }}</ng-container>
```

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

In any latest Angular project, that is using `@angular/language-service` apply code snippets from the description.

```
Node: 10.15.0
OS: darwin x64
Angular: 7.2.0
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... http, language-service, platform-browser
... platform-browser-dynamic, router
```

**Anything else relevant?**

If required I can create a repository with the code snippets. I didn't do so because it should be easy to reproduce. If I am wrong, please let me know and I will provide the repo.

Issues.Title: Use shared `DomElementSchemaRegistry` instance for `ServerRendererFactory2`
Issues.Body:
### Relevant Package

This performance improvement is for `@angular/platform-server`.

### Problem

Right now the `ServerRendererFactory2` creates a new instance of the `DomElementSchemaRegistry` for each and every request, which is quite costly (for the Tour of Heroes SSR example this takes around **15%** of the overall execution time).

A [0x](https://www.npmjs.com/package/0x) flamegraph illustrates the problem:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/815988/51188953-4bccd700-18df-11e9-8232-8ae8f9ec49d7.png)

### Solution

Since the schema is never modified, but only used in a read-only fashion, it should be possible to re-use a single instance instead, which avoids quite a bit of overhead per request.

We can verify the improvement using another 0x flamegraph:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/815988/51189001-62732e00-18df-11e9-8de3-dd64ab157769.png)

Issues.Title: Router.navigateByUrl does not support question mark "encoded" by HttpUrlEncodingCodec
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
The issue is caused by package `@angular/router`, but `@angular/common/http` is related.

### Description

The querystring serialized with `HttpParams` using the default `HttpUrlEncodingCodec` is not compatible with `Router.navigateByUrl` if a value contains a question mark.

The documentation (https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/7.2.0/packages/common/http/src/params.ts#L25) of `HttpUrlEncodingCodec` states it is using `encodeURIComponent` to serialize and URL parameter keys and values:

> A `HttpParameterCodec` that uses `encodeURIComponent` and `decodeURIComponent` to serialize and parse URL parameter keys and values.

In fact, this is not true. As far as I have found, the difference and reasoning is explained here: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/7.2.0/packages/http/src/url_search_params.ts#L55 (By the way, some part of this comment could be migrated from this deprecated `URLSearchParams` class to its replacement `HttpParams`).

> By default, `QueryEncoder` encodes keys and values of parameters using `encodeURIComponent`, and then un-encodes certain characters that are allowed to be part of the query according to IETF RFC 3986: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986.
>
> These are the characters that are not encoded: `! $ \' ( ) * + , ; A 9 - . _ ~ ? /`
>
> If the set of allowed query characters is not acceptable for a particular backend, `QueryEncoder` can be subclassed and provided as the 2nd argument to URLSearchParams.

In this issue, it is not "a particular backend", it is actually the angular router which does not handle well the question mark character if it is not encoded. If I override the  `encodeValue` of `HttpUrlEncodingCodec` to really use `encodeURIComponent`, the router is working as expected.

Please fix the router to support these query params in `Router.navigateByUrl`. Otherwise change the `HttpUrlEncodingCodec` to encode the question mark as well to make it consistent across the code of the framework.

Issues.Title: fix(@schematics/angular): remove SCSS from ng-new prompt
Issues.Body:
The stylesheet extension `.sass` should be deprecated in favor of `.scss`.
See SASS documentation [here](http://sass-lang.com/guide).

In `ng new`, the **value** `scss` generates stylesheets with `.scss`
extension whereas the **value** `sass` generates stylesheets with
`.sass` extension. 
We want `.scss` extension. However, the **label** for `.scss` extension should
be SASS.

This is a non-breaking change since it only affect new CLI projects.

Issues.Title: fix(@schematics/angular): stop offering SASS option for ng new
Issues.Body:

This change does not remove any support for projects which were already created with ".sass" files, we simply stop offering
this option when creating new projects.

Also correct the capitalization of Less based on how they spell it on their website.

Issues.Title: feat(@angular/cli): option to build and test only specified spec files
Issues.Body:
A new `--spec` option is added. It is a glob/pattern that specifies which specs should be included in the build. 

Command:
 `ng test --spec=app/services/auth*`

When karma is already running, selected spec can be updated by running following command: 
`ng test --spec=app/login* --spec-update`

Few rules are applied to the pattern to make certain things possible:
* `.spec.ts` is added automatically if missing (less typing)
* if it ends with `*.ts` and doesn't have `.spec.ts`, extension will be replaced with `.spec.ts`
* if path starts at root, source root directory will be trimmed. So that you could use relative file path from editor to make custom tasks to run the command


Behind the scenes a new `test.generated.ts` is saved next to original `test.ts` which instead of using `require.context` imports all matching files. This gives quite a big boost in the project at work (at least 10s on each iterative build!)

Fixes #3603

Motivation: It is a pain in a big application to wait until entire app is rebuilt just to run single `fit` block. Takes almost a minute with 4000+ tests and barely works when code coverage is enabled. 

Missing: docs(?)

Example tasks for vscode:
````
{
  // See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
  // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
  "version": "2.0.0",
  "tasks": [
    {
      "type": "shell",
      "label": "test selected spec",
      "command": "node_modules/.bin/ng",
      "args": [
        "test",
        "--spec",
        "${relativeFile}"
      ],
      "problemMatcher": []
    },
    {
      "type": "shell",
      "label": "switch selected spec",
      "command": "node_modules/.bin/ng",
      "args": [
        "test",
        "--spec",
        "${relativeFile}",
        "--spec-update"
      ],
      "problemMatcher": [],
      "isBackground": true
    }
  ]
}
````

PS. The setup for writing tests is quite nice!

-->


### Repro steps
Try to do your component imports for your module dynamically off a directory
```
import * as components from 'app/components';

const componentsArray = [];
Object.keys(components).forEach(name => componentsArray.push(components[name]));

@NgModule({
  declarations: [
    AppComponent,
    ...componentsArray
  ],
  imports: [
    BrowserModule,
  ],
  bootstrap: [
    AppComponent
  ]
})
export class AppModule { }
```

### The log given by the failure
<!-- Normally this include a stack trace and some more information. -->
ERROR in : Cannot determine the module for class SampleComponent in /.../projects/example/src/app/components/sample-component/sample.component.ts! Add SampleComponent to the NgModule to fix it.
Cannot determine the module for class OtherSampleComponent in /.../projects/example/src/app/components/other-sample/other-sample.component.ts! Add OtherSampleComponent to the NgModule to fix it.


### Desired functionality
When you have a project with a large count of components it can be a maintenance hazard to have a list of 100 imports. It's an easy step to forget when someone adds a new component, or renames them, or moves them to a different subdirectory. Using index.ts files you can get them all exported to a top-level directory, and then iterate over the import to get them all added to your module. This works fine for development but when I run a prod build it thinks I've never imported the components, even though they clearly are. As near as I can tell the only reason for this is that the names don't show up as an explicit import in the file itself.

I've done some console logging and confirmed that the output of this method is identical to if I just statically add them to the declarations array. There are no stray elements getting in, and every component is listed. 

I assume I'm missing some understanding of how the aot compilation handles index files and how that impacts this approach.


### Mention any other details that might be useful
This approach only seems to fail for components inside prod/aot builds. For non-prod/aot builds it works fine, for adding services to the module's providers it works, for importing ngrx effects it works.
